ud1.8:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ud1.8:1.3: Now at that time around Venerable Saṅgāmaji had arrived at Sāvatthī to see the Buddha.
ud1.8:1.6: and went to the Jetavana, taking their boy.
ud1.8:2.1: Now at that time Venerable Saṅgāmaji was sitting at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.
ud1.8:2.2: Then his former wife went up to him and said,
ud1.8:2.3: “I have a little child, ascetic, so please provide for me.”
ud1.8:2.4: When she said this, Saṅgāmaji kept silent.
ud1.8:3.1: For a second time she said,
ud1.8:3.2: “I have a little child, ascetic, so please provide for me.”
ud1.8:3.3: For a second time, Saṅgāmaji kept silent.
ud1.8:4.1: For a third time she said,
ud1.8:4.2: “I have a little child, ascetic, so please provide for me.”
ud1.8:4.3: For a third time, Saṅgāmaji kept silent.
ud1.8:5.1: Then she put down the boy in front of Saṅgāmaji, saying,
ud1.8:5.2: “This is your child, ascetic. Provide for him.”
ud1.8:6.1: But Saṅgāmaji neither looked at the boy nor spoke to him.
ud1.8:6.2: Then his former wife went a little distance away. Looking back, she saw Saṅgāmaji ignoring the boy, and thought,
ud1.8:6.3: “This ascetic doesn’t even want his child.”
ud1.8:6.4: She returned to pick up the boy, then left.
ud1.8:6.5: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha saw how Saṅgāmaji’s went back for the child.
ud1.8:7.1: Then, knowing the meaning of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ud1.8:8.1: “When she came he was not glad,
ud1.8:8.2: when she left he did not grieve.
ud1.8:8.3: Victorious in battle, freed from chains,
ud1.8:8.4: that’s who I call a brahmin.”
